study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the Health-Related Quality of Life (HRQoL) of Italian children with coeliac disease and their parents using the adapted Coeliac Disease Dutch Questionnaire (CDDUX).
results_summary: The Italian CDDUX was found to be valid and reliable, with mean scores indicating a neutral evaluation of quality of life in children (52.6 ± 17.2) and parents (49.5 ± 17.9). The study did not directly measure the efficacy of a gluten-free diet but focused on HRQoL assessment tools.
population_specificity: Italian children aged 8-18 years with coeliac disease and their parents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a gluten-free diet on conditions like celiac disease, nonceliac gluten sensitivity, and irritable bowel syndrome, while also assessing potential nutritional deficiencies.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet effectively treats celiac disease and related conditions but may lead to micronutrient deficiencies and macronutrient imbalances, including higher sugar and lipid intake. The diet's popularity has increased availability but also raised costs of gluten-free products.
population_specificity: Genetically predisposed individuals with celiac disease, nonceliac gluten sensitivity, or irritable bowel syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish a criterion for clinical follow-up frequency for celiac disease patients on a gluten-free diet, using data mining to assess adherence via gluten immunogenic peptides in stools.
results_summary: The study found that patients on a gluten-free diet for more than two years had poorer compliance and required more frequent follow-up, contrary to common clinical practice. Males and long-term dieters showed higher gluten exposure, while children adhered better than teenagers or adults.
population_specificity: 188 celiac disease patients (75% children under 14 years old) on a gluten-free diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the persistence of villous atrophy after 2 years on a strict gluten-free diet in adult celiac disease patients, assessing the role of inadvertent gluten exposure.
results_summary: Persistent villous atrophy was observed in 53% of patients despite strict dietary control, with 69% showing detectable gluten immunogenic peptides in fecal samples. Older age was significantly associated with persistent villous atrophy, but no differences in gluten exposure levels were found between those with atrophy and those who recovered.
population_specificity: Symptomatic adult patients with newly diagnosed celiac disease (mean age 36.5 ± 1.6 years, 73% women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a gluten-free diet (GFD) on the quality of life of patients with axial spondyloarthritis (SpA).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study is ongoing or not yet published.
population_specificity: Patients with axial spondyloarthritis (n=200).
effective_dosage: Experimental arm: ≥6 gluten-free breads/day + 200g gluten-free penne pasta/week + 6 rice flavor capsules/day. Control arm: ≥6 gluten-containing breads/day + 200g gluten-containing penne pasta/week + 6 vital gluten-containing capsules/day.
study_duration: 16-week intervention followed by an 8-week open-label period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure the level of unintended gluten contamination in the daily diet of celiac children following a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that only 2.7% of food samples contained detectable gluten, with most below 20 ppm, and daily gluten intake remained well below the 10 mg/day safety threshold. The findings suggest that unintended gluten exposure in treated celiac children is very low in a high-awareness setting.
population_specificity: Celiac disease children (2-18 years old) on a gluten-free diet for ≥6 months.
effective_dosage: Not specified (gluten content measured in ppm).
study_duration: Data collected over a 24-hour period (study conducted from April 2019 to December 2019).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and long-term prognosis of a gluten-free diet (GFD) in treating dermatitis herpetiformis (DH), a cutaneous manifestation of celiac disease.
results_summary: The study found that a strict lifelong GFD is the treatment of choice for DH, offering an excellent long-term prognosis with normal quality of life and all-cause mortality. Most patients initially required dapsone to control symptoms, but it could be discontinued after a mean of 2 years on GFD.
population_specificity: Adults with dermatitis herpetiformis, predominantly males, with a mean age of onset around 50 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of fecal gluten immunogenic peptides (GIPs) in detecting duodenal lesions in celiac disease patients on a gluten-free diet (GFD) and compare them with serum anti-tTG antibodies.
results_summary: The study found that fecal GIPs had similar sensitivity (33%) and specificity (81%) to anti-tTG antibodies in detecting duodenal mucosal damage. GIPs were associated with self-reported gluten consumption but not with questionnaire scores on GFD adherence or quality of life.
population_specificity: Adolescents and adults with celiac disease maintaining a long-lasting gluten-free diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of histopathology in assessing the response to a gluten-free diet in managing inflammatory malabsorptive processes, particularly in coeliac disease.
results_summary: The study highlights that a gluten-free diet can improve villous architecture in coeliac disease, aiding in the management of malabsorption. Histopathology helps differentiate coeliac disease from other inflammatory conditions with similar duodenal changes.
population_specificity: Individuals with inflammatory malabsorptive processes, particularly coeliac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether dietitian-led nutrition education could improve eating and bowel habits in children with celiac disease on a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that nutrition education significantly improved compliance with dietary reference values for fat, carbohydrates, and fiber, leading to better-balanced diets in children with celiac disease.
population_specificity: 72 children (58.3% girls) with celiac disease, mean age 10.2 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify associations between the clinical characteristics of coeliac disease and oral manifestations, and to assess the role of a gluten-free diet in managing these symptoms.
results_summary: The study found significant associations between coeliac disease and oral manifestations like caries prevalence and dentin sensitivity. Following a gluten-free diet was linked to better control of gingival bleeding and management of oral symptoms.
population_specificity: 237 individuals with coeliac disease (76.7% female, age range 15 to 56+ years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence supporting the efficacy of a gluten-free diet in managing irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that the benefits of a gluten-free diet in IBS are likely due to the reduction of FODMAPs rather than gluten itself, suggesting limited direct efficacy of gluten elimination.
population_specificity: Patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the role of gluten in non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS) and gut-brain interaction disorders, including its clinical features, pathophysiology, and management.
results_summary: The study found that some patients report symptom improvement on a gluten-free diet, but the benefits are limited, and long-term consequences may include nutritional and gut microbiota imbalances. The mechanisms of NCGS remain unclear, though research suggests links to gut motility, permeability, and innate immunity changes.
population_specificity: Individuals with self-reported gluten-related complaints, including those with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent advances in understanding non-celiac wheat sensitivity (NCWS), focusing on clinical and etiological controversies, diagnostic criteria, and histological aspects.
results_summary: The study found that NCWS diagnosis relies on symptom improvement with a gluten-free diet and symptom reappearance after gluten challenge, though the condition's etiology remains unclear. The Salerno criteria may aid accurate diagnosis, but self-labeling via social media complicates the process.
population_specificity: Individuals with non-celiac wheat sensitivity (NCWS) after excluding celiac disease and wheat allergy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the appropriateness of a gluten-free diet (GFD) for non-celiac gluten/wheat sensitivity (NCG/WS) and explore other dietary approaches like low-FODMAP diets (LFD).
results_summary: The study suggests GFD may be suitable for self-reported gluten/wheat-dependent symptoms, but other compounds like FODMAPs, ATIs, WGA, and glyphosate may also contribute to symptoms. A low-FODMAP diet is recommended as a first-line option for FODMAP-related symptoms and second-line for non-responsive GFD cases.
population_specificity: Individuals with non-celiac gluten/wheat sensitivity (NCG/WS) and self-reported gluten/wheat-dependent symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current knowledge on the ability of probiotic strains to digest gliadin peptides in vitro and modulate inflammatory responses in the gut, as an alternative or complementary therapy to a gluten-free diet for celiac disease.
results_summary: The study found that probiotic supplementation shows potential for immune-modulation, restoring gut microbiota, and reducing immunogenic peptides, with positive effects such as inhibition of pro-inflammatory cytokine TNF-α. However, the abstract does not provide specific quantitative results or statistical significance.
population_specificity: Individuals with celiac disease or gluten-related disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to support gastroenterologists and nutritionists in managing celiac disease (CeD) patients during the COVID-19 pandemic, focusing on the impact of restrictions on gluten-free diet adherence.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on gluten-free diet effects but highlights the lack of data on COVID-19 risks and outcomes in CeD patients and the potential impact of pandemic restrictions on CeD treatment.
population_specificity: Celiac disease (CeD) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current understanding of gluten-free diet as a treatment for coeliac disease and explore potential alternative therapies.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet is safe and often effective for coeliac disease but faces challenges like high cost, restrictive nature, and perceived quality of life issues, leading to inadequate disease control in some patients. Additionally, a subgroup of patients does not respond adequately, and mucosal healing may remain incomplete.
population_specificity: Genetically susceptible individuals with coeliac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the possible role of a Gluten-Free Diet (GFD) in managing Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: The study found that a GFD is less restrictive and easier to implement for IBS patients who clearly recognize gluten as a trigger of their symptoms, though the evidence supporting its efficacy is of very low quality.
population_specificity: Patients with Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) who identify gluten as a symptom trigger.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current understanding of coeliac disease (CD), its diverse clinical manifestations, and the role of a lifelong gluten-free diet as the primary treatment.
results_summary: The study highlights that a strict gluten-free diet remains the only effective treatment for CD, with increasing recognition of non-classical and asymptomatic presentations. Novel therapeutic agents are under investigation but are not yet established alternatives.
population_specificity: Individuals of all ages with coeliac disease, including children with classical, mild, or asymptomatic presentations.
study_duration: Lifelong (implied by the nature of the treatment)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish best practice guidelines for diagnosing and managing patients with suspected celiac disease but negative serologic test results, including the role of a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet can help confirm a diagnosis of seronegative celiac disease if clinical and histologic improvements are observed after 1-3 years. It also emphasized the importance of thorough diagnostic testing and dietary review to rule out other causes of enteropathy.
population_specificity: Patients with suspected celiac disease but negative serologic test results.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the challenges faced by celiac patients in maintaining a strict gluten-free diet and explore approaches to address these problems.
results_summary: The study highlights the growing gluten-free food market but identifies significant obstacles such as limited availability, high costs, insufficient labeling, cross-contamination risks, and psychological factors affecting adherence. It also notes the lack of awareness about gluten-free diets among non-celiac individuals.
population_specificity: Celiac patients and individuals considering a gluten-free diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether gluten ingestion increases symptoms in patients with NCGS and to assess compliance with a gluten-free diet using stool and urine GIPs.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in symptom severity between gluten and placebo ingestion in NCGS patients. NCGS patients were more adherent to the gluten-free diet than healthy controls but had higher baseline symptom severity. Neither group experienced significantly increased symptoms after gluten ingestion.
population_specificity: 30 patients with non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS) and 43 healthy controls.
effective_dosage: 0.5 g/d or 2 g/d of gluten for 7 days each.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the evidence on the efficacy of dietary regimens, including a gluten-free diet, for treating epilepsy, focusing on pathophysiological mechanisms, safety, and tolerability.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that a gluten-free diet may exert beneficial effects on neuroprotection and refractory epilepsy, but specific outcomes or statistical significance are not detailed.
population_specificity: Pediatric and adult populations with drug-resistant epilepsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review pediatric literature on the cephalalgic features of children with celiac disease (CD) and evaluate the potential benefits of a gluten-free diet (GFD) on neurological symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that while the prevalence of headache in children with CD remains controversial, adherence to a GFD appears to improve neurological symptoms, though the underlying mechanism is not fully understood.
population_specificity: Children with celiac disease (pediatric age group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the challenges and limitations of a gluten-free diet (GFD) for celiac disease patients, including adherence issues, nutritional imbalances, and gut microbiota restoration.
results_summary: The study highlights that GFD, while the only treatment for celiac disease, poses concerns like food cross-contamination, nutritional deficiencies, and incomplete gut microbiota recovery. It suggests potential benefits of supplementing GFD with probiotics.
population_specificity: Celiac disease patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a Persian-language smartphone application on celiac patients' knowledge and adherence to a gluten-free diet compared to conventional clinical education.
results_summary: The smartphone application significantly improved patients' knowledge about gluten-free foods and adherence to a gluten-free diet compared to conventional education, as measured by post-intervention scores and the CDAT.
population_specificity: 60 celiac patients with a mean disease duration of 4.38 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent updates in celiac disease, including the role of gluten exposure, diagnostic guidelines, and the efficacy of gluten-free diets (GFD) and emerging treatments like latiglutenase.
results_summary: The study highlights that GFD adherence can be monitored via gluten immunogenic peptides (GIPs) in stool, and latiglutenase shows promise in reducing symptoms and improving quality of life for celiac patients. Updated guidelines now allow serology-based diagnosis in some cases, reducing the need for biopsies.
population_specificity: Genetically predisposed individuals, children, and adults with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of a gluten-free diet (GFD) and other therapeutic strategies, such as nutraceuticals, to mitigate neurological dysfunction in celiac disease and non-celiac gluten sensitivity.
results_summary: The study suggests that early diagnosis and strict adherence to a GFD may help prevent neurological dysfunction in celiac patients, but better therapeutic strategies are needed. Nutraceuticals, including phyto and synthetic cannabinoids, are proposed as potential adjuncts to GFD for improving outcomes.
population_specificity: Celiac disease patients with neurological manifestations and non-celiac gluten sensitivity individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential role of gluten and the effects of a gluten-free diet (GFD) in non-celiac patients with multiple sclerosis (MS), psoriasis, type 1 diabetes (T1D), and autoimmune thyroid diseases (ATDs).
results_summary: The study found limited and mixed evidence for the efficacy of a GFD in non-celiac patients. Significant results were reported in one MS trial with methodological limitations, and beneficial effects were noted in a subset of seropositive psoriasis patients. No clear effects were observed in seronegative psoriasis patients or T1D, and no studies were available for ATDs.
population_specificity: Non-celiac patients with MS, psoriasis, T1D, or ATDs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of probiotics as an adjuvant treatment for improving gastrointestinal symptoms and quality of life in patients with celiac disease adhering to a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: Probiotics improved GI symptoms when assessed by the GI Symptoms Rating Scale but showed no difference when different questionnaires were pooled. Bifidobacteria levels increased after probiotic use, but insufficient data were available for tumor necrosis factor-α levels or quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease (n = 279 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the mechanisms of iron deficiency anemia (IDA) in celiac disease (CD) and the persistence of IDA despite adherence to a gluten-free diet (GFD), as well as potential therapeutic implications.
results_summary: The study found that some celiac patients continue to experience IDA despite GFD and mucosal healing, possibly due to ultrastructural and molecular alterations in enterocytes. Non-celiac gluten sensitivity patients also showed anemia linked to similar intestinal alterations.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease and non-celiac gluten sensitivity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of an iron-rich gluten-free diet versus oral iron supplementation in treating iron deficiency without anemia in women with celiac disease.
results_summary: The study found that an iron-rich diet was not as effective as ferrous sulfate supplementation in improving iron levels but was well-tolerated and increased daily iron intake, suggesting potential long-term benefits for patients intolerant to pharmacological treatment.
population_specificity: Female celiac disease patients of child-bearing age with iron deficiency without anemia.
effective_dosage: Iron-rich diet (>20 mg/day) versus ferrous sulfate (105 mg/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether alterations in intestinal microbiota in children with celiac disease are caused by the disease itself or by treatment with a gluten-free diet (GFD).
results_summary: The study found that microbial dysbiosis was not observed in children with new-onset celiac disease, but a GFD explained small variations in microbiota composition. Specific bacterial biomarkers for celiac disease were identified, and fecal levels of butyrate and ammonia decreased during GFD treatment.
population_specificity: 141 children (20 with new-onset celiac disease, 45 on a GFD, 57 healthy children, and 19 unaffected siblings of children with celiac disease) in Glasgow, Scotland.
study_duration: Follow-up at 6 and 12 months for 13 children with new-onset celiac disease on a GFD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence on the effectiveness of gluten-free diet in managing IBS symptoms.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on the gluten-free diet's effects, only mentioning it as one of the diets examined in the review.
population_specificity: Patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare genetic background, diagnosis characteristics, well-being, and adherence to a gluten-free diet between patients with familial or sporadic celiac disease.
results_summary: Familial celiac disease cases had milder symptoms at diagnosis, fewer current symptoms, and better quality of life compared to sporadic cases, though dietary adherence and gastrointestinal symptoms were similar. High-risk genotypes were more common in familial cases, but they still showed better outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease (familial or sporadic), totaling 1064 individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the necessity and challenges of a gluten-free diet for celiac disease (CeD) patients and explore potential pharmacological treatments to complement it.
results_summary: The study found that a strict gluten-free diet is the only current treatment for CeD but is difficult to maintain and often insufficient due to high sensitivity to trace gluten. Oral enzyme therapy, such as gluten-degrading enzymes, shows promise as a complementary treatment.
population_specificity: Individuals with celiac disease (CeD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical usefulness of urine gluten immunogenic peptides (GIP) as a biomarker for monitoring gluten-free diet (GFD) adherence in celiac patients and assess its concordance with mucosal damage.
results_summary: The study found that urine GIP testing had high sensitivity (94%) and negative predictive value (97%) in detecting gluten exposure and predicting the absence of histological lesions. Many patients with mucosal damage had detectable GIP despite being asymptomatic and reporting GFD adherence.
population_specificity: 22 de novo celiac disease patients, 77 celiac patients on a GFD, and 13 nonceliac subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of budesonide in inducing clinical and histologic response in non-responsive celiac disease (NRCD) with villous atrophy, particularly focusing on symptom relief and mucosal recovery.
results_summary: Budesonide showed a 57% clinical response rate in NRCD patients, with higher efficacy in those presenting with diarrhea and receiving dietitian counseling. However, 79% of responders experienced symptomatic relapse, and mucosal recovery was observed in only 11/24 cases with follow-up biopsies.
population_specificity: Adults with non-responsive celiac disease and villous atrophy (77% female, median age 45.0 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of gut microbiota in the pathogenesis of coeliac disease and assess potential therapeutic strategies, including probiotics and prebiotics, as adjuncts to a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that coeliac disease patients exhibit gut microbial dysbiosis, characterized by increased gram-negative bacteria and reduced anti-inflammatory bacteria, which may contribute to immune dysregulation. The efficacy of gut microbiota modulators like probiotics and prebiotics as adjunct treatments to a gluten-free diet remains unproven and requires further investigation.
population_specificity: Patients with coeliac disease and potential influences on gut microbiota in infancy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent findings on how a gluten-free diet (GFD) modulates gut microbiota in healthy individuals, celiac disease (CD) patients, and non-celiac gluten/wheat sensitivity (NCG/WS) patients.
results_summary: The study highlights that a gluten-free diet is the only effective treatment for CD and NCG/WS, with gut microbiota playing a key role in maintaining gut integrity, immune response, and inflammation linked to these conditions. The review suggests GFD impacts microbiota composition, though specific outcomes vary by population.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals, celiac disease (CD) patients, and non-celiac gluten/wheat sensitivity (NCG/WS) patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of gluten-free or low-gluten diets in managing inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) by examining clinical associations with celiac disease and non-celiac gluten sensitivity.
results_summary: The study found no prospective evidence supporting the universal use of a gluten-free diet (GFD) for IBD, though cross-sectional reports suggest symptom improvement in some patients. Animal studies indicate gluten may promote intestinal inflammation, but human clinical data are lacking.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), including Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, as well as those with celiac disease (CeD) or non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of supplementing a gluten-free diet with prebiotic oligofructose-enriched inulin on intestinal permeability in children with celiac disease.
results_summary: The study found that prebiotic supplementation did not significantly improve gut barrier integrity but increased mannitol excretion, suggesting potential epithelial surface expansion. Some children with elevated baseline permeability markers showed improvement in calprotectin and sugar absorption test results after prebiotic intake.
population_specificity: 34 children with celiac disease on a strict gluten-free diet.
effective_dosage: 10 g per day of oligofructose-enriched inulin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a gluten-free diet on bone mineral density (BMD) in premenopausal women with osteoporosis secondary to celiac disease.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet led to a 9% increase in radius trabecular volumetric density after one year in premenopausal women with celiac disease, indicating improved BMD. No fracture reduction data was available.
population_specificity: Premenopausal women with osteoporosis secondary to celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between Vitamin D levels and celiac disease (CeD) and assess the impact of a gluten-free diet (GFD) on restoring Vitamin D levels in CeD patients.
results_summary: The study found that CeD patients had significantly lower serum 25(OH)D levels compared to controls, but after GFD treatment, their levels increased by 15.6 nmol/L and approached those of healthy controls. No difference in VDR genotypes was observed between CeD patients and controls.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease (CeD) and healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet and low-FODMAP diet in managing symptoms of noncoeliac gluten sensitivity (NCGS) and to explore diagnostic challenges.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet and low-FODMAP diet play a significant role in managing NCGS symptoms, though diagnostic and treatment guidelines remain unclear. Nutritional support, including pre/probiotics, should be tailored to individual patients.
population_specificity: Individuals with noncoeliac gluten sensitivity (NCGS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a gluten-free diet (GFD) could induce remission of subclinical lymphocytic hypophysitis (LYH) or prevent its progression to clinical stage in patients with celiac disease (CD).
results_summary: The study found that 34% of patients with LYH and CD achieved complete remission of LYH after a GFD, compared to only 2% in the isolated LYH group. The presence of CD was the only independent predictor of pituitary function recovery.
population_specificity: Newly diagnosed LYH patients with high titer of antipituitary antibodies (APA) and normal or subclinically impaired pituitary function, grouped into those with CD (n=43) and those without CD (n=50).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the rare but severe presentation of coeliac crisis in undiagnosed coeliac disease (CD) and its management through a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that coeliac crisis, though rare, can present with severe electrolyte imbalances and hypoproteinaemia, requiring urgent management. A gluten-free diet was implied as the treatment, but efficacy in crisis resolution was not explicitly measured.
population_specificity: Young female with coeliac crisis (a rare acute presentation of CD), compared to literature cases predominantly in older males.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a gluten-free diet as the only effective treatment for celiac disease by interrupting the immune response to gluten peptides.
results_summary: The study found that a lifelong gluten-free diet effectively interrupts the immune response to gluten peptides, preventing damage to the intestinal mucosa and serving as the sole treatment for celiac disease. It also highlighted the correlation between intestinal microbiota and celiac disease, as well as the potential role of microRNAs as biomarkers.
population_specificity: Genetically predisposed individuals with celiac disease, including pediatric and adult populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify pitfalls in the diagnosis of gluten-related disorders (GRD) and provide a methodological approach to avoid misdiagnosis and unnecessary gluten-free diet prescriptions.
results_summary: The study highlights that misdiagnosis of GRD can lead to overtreatment with gluten-free diets and wasted healthcare resources, emphasizing the need for accurate diagnostic criteria, particularly for non-coeliac gluten sensitivity (NCGS).
population_specificity: Individuals with gluten-related disorders (coeliac disease, dermatitis herpetiformis, gluten ataxia, wheat allergy, and non-coeliac gluten sensitivity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a gluten-free diet on gut microbiota and disease evolution in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on the gluten-free diet's effects, only mentioning it as one of several diets investigated for IBD management. No clear indications toward its efficacy were noted.
population_specificity: Individuals with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on celiac disease, its nutritional consequences, and the potential impact of bariatric surgery on weight loss, nutritional deficiencies, and response to a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study reviewed existing literature but did not present new findings on the gluten-free diet's effects. It highlighted the lack of research on bariatric surgery in celiac disease patients with overweight or obesity.
population_specificity: Individuals with celiac disease, particularly those with overweight or obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and histological response of pediatric patients with collagenous gastritis to various treatments, including a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet showed relatively good rates of clinical improvement in pediatric patients with collagenous gastritis, though histological remission remained difficult to achieve.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (43 cases, M/F ratio 1:2) diagnosed with collagenous gastritis.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to systematically review treatment options for delayed pressure urticaria (DPU), not Gluten-Free Diet.
results_summary: The study did not investigate Gluten-Free Diet; it focused on treatments like antihistamines, montelukast, omalizumab, and sulphones for DPU.
population_specificity: Patients with delayed pressure urticaria (DPU).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of gut microbiota in Celiac Disease (CD) pathogenesis and the potential use of probiotics as an adjunct to a gluten-free diet (GFD) for prevention and treatment.
results_summary: The study suggests that microbiota manipulation, particularly through probiotics, may influence CD pathogenesis and could serve as an adjunct to GFD for symptom improvement, though therapeutic applications remain speculative.
population_specificity: Genetically predisposed individuals with Celiac Disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess celiac disease screening rates and the impact of a gluten-free diet on glycemic outcomes in asymptomatic patients with type 1 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that celiac disease was frequently observed in asymptomatic type 1 diabetes patients. A gluten-free diet was associated with changes in HbA1c, though specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Asymptomatic patients with type 1 diabetes, aged 8-45 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review nutrient deficiencies in pediatric and adult celiac disease patients at diagnosis and during gluten-free diet (GFD) treatment, and assess their impact on management strategies, including potential supplementation.
results_summary: Nutrient deficiencies are common in celiac disease patients at diagnosis and during GFD treatment, often due to inadequate dietary intake or impaired absorption. While most deficiencies improve with long-term GFD or supplementation, some persist or worsen during GFD.
population_specificity: Pediatric and adult celiac disease patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a gluten-free diet (GFD) could improve symptoms in patients with refractory functional dyspepsia (RFD) and identify cases of non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS).
results_summary: Among 77 RFD patients, 35% showed symptom improvement on GFD, with 6.4% (18% of responders) experiencing symptom recurrence after gluten challenge, suggesting NCGS. Extra-intestinal symptoms like fatigue, pain, and headache also improved in NCGS patients on GFD.
population_specificity: Patients with refractory functional dyspepsia (RFD) excluding celiac disease, wheat allergy, and H. pylori infection.
study_duration: 6 weeks (GFD), followed by 3 months of follow-up

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate diagnostic criteria for coeliac disease in children with selective IgA deficiency and assess the impact of a gluten-free diet on serological markers.
results_summary: The study found that despite good dietary adherence and symptom remission, 52% of children remained ATG IgG-positive after 2 years on a gluten-free diet. Diagnostic criteria varied, with IgG serology often used equivalently to IgA isotype, even when not addressed in guidelines.
population_specificity: Children under 15 years with selective IgA deficiency diagnosed with coeliac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential benefits of a gluten-free diet as a therapeutic intervention for improving behavioral changes and reducing malnutrition in individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet yielded positive outcomes, including behavioral improvements and reduced malnutrition, potentially linked to gluten allergies or intolerances in individuals with ASD.
population_specificity: Individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize studies examining nutrition assessment, interventions, and measures to monitor gluten-free diet (GFD) adherence/compliance in patients with celiac disease (CD).
results_summary: The review found that most studies focused on GFD and oats, with increasing attention on prebiotics/probiotics and education programs. Systematic reviews and evidence-based guidelines were available for GFD and oats, but gaps remained for other interventions.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease (CD).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the immune-mediated mechanisms by which gluten ingestion damages the small intestinal mucosa in genetically susceptible individuals with celiac disease.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that gluten ingestion leads to damage of the small intestinal mucosa in celiac disease, primarily induced by IFN-γ production from intestinal CD4 cells. No specific results regarding a gluten-free diet are provided.
population_specificity: Genetically susceptible individuals with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify patient-centered symptom, impact, and HRQoL concepts in celiac disease and evaluate relevant PRO instruments for use in clinical trials of new CD treatments.
results_summary: The study identified gastrointestinal and extra-intestinal symptoms as most important to treat, with the Celiac Disease Symptom Diary and Celiac Disease Patient Reported Outcome instrument deemed most appropriate but with limitations. Payers emphasized measuring symptom frequency and severity, particularly for patients nonresponsive to a gluten-free diet.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease, clinicians, payers, and a patient advocate (n=21).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a gluten-free diet (GFD) slows the decline in beta-cell capacity in non-coeliac children with recently diagnosed type 1 diabetes.
results_summary: The GFD group showed a marginally slower decline in C-peptide levels, lower insulin dose, and better HbA1c and IDAA1c at 12 months compared to controls, though the C-peptide difference was not statistically strong. No significant differences were found in carbohydrate intake or quality of life between groups.
population_specificity: Non-coeliac children (aged 10.2 ± 3.3 years) with recently diagnosed type 1 diabetes.
effective_dosage: Not specified (self-selected GFD adherence verified by stool immunoreactive gluten and food questionnaires).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the causes of non-responsive coeliac disease (NRCD) in adults, outline a systematic approach for investigation, and evaluate the latest management strategies for this subset of coeliac disease.
results_summary: The study found that while most individuals with coeliac disease improve on a gluten-free diet (GFD), up to 30% experience persistent symptoms or inflammation, classified as NRCD, which may stem from dietary indiscretion, slow healing, refractory disease, or alternative conditions. The review highlights diagnostic and management approaches for NRCD.
population_specificity: Adults with coeliac disease, particularly those with non-responsive symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet in treating dermatitis herpetiformis (DH) and its associated enteropathy.
results_summary: The study found that a lifelong gluten-free diet effectively resolves the rash and enteropathy in DH, improves quality of life, and offers a good long-term prognosis.
population_specificity: Patients with dermatitis herpetiformis (DH), an autoimmune skin disease linked to coeliac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current clinical and experimental literature on nutritional interventions, including gluten-free diets, for managing gastrointestinal and behavioral symptoms in individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on gluten-free diets but indicates that no consensus exists on optimal nutritional therapy for ASD, leaving patients and physicians to choose from various dietary protocols.
population_specificity: Individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing literature on coeliac disease and gluten-free diet in Pakistan to assess the current state of knowledge and identify gaps.
results_summary: The study found a lack of high-quality scientific literature on coeliac disease and gluten-free diet in Pakistan, with most publications being small case reports or series. Only five articles addressed treatment issues, including gluten-free diet, indicating limited evidence on efficacy.
population_specificity: Adults and paediatric patients in Pakistan (specifically Sindh and Punjab).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the limitations of a gluten-free diet (GFD) for celiac disease and explore the need for alternative therapeutic approaches.
results_summary: The study found that a GFD is the only recommended therapy for celiac disease but is difficult to comply with and ineffective in some active cases, highlighting the need for nondietary treatments.
population_specificity: Genetically susceptible populations with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review non-dietary therapies for coeliac disease as alternatives or complements to a gluten-free diet, focusing on six therapeutic strategies.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet is the only effective treatment for coeliac disease but is perceived as burdensome, prompting research into alternative therapies. Most developing therapies are in pre-clinical phases, with few in advanced trials, suggesting they may only complement gluten withdrawal rather than replace it.
population_specificity: Genetically predisposed subjects with coeliac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare gluten-sensitive enteropathy in Irish Setters to human celiac disease and evaluate the necessity of a gluten-free diet for diagnosis and therapy.
results_summary: The study found that gluten-sensitive enteropathy in Irish Setters resembles human celiac disease, with intestinal lesions and symptoms like chronic diarrhea and weight loss. A gluten-free diet was essential for both diagnosis and treatment.
population_specificity: Irish Setters with gluten-sensitive enteropathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a gluten-free diet as a first-line treatment option for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: The abstract suggests that a gluten-free diet is among the dietary changes recommended for IBS patients, but compliance is challenging due to strict food elimination. It provides symptom relief for a subset of patients, though evidence for its efficacy is not strongly emphasized.
population_specificity: Patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review different gluten detection methods to ensure the safety of gluten-free products for celiac patients.
results_summary: The study highlights the challenges of gluten contamination in allegedly gluten-free products and reviews various detection methods, emphasizing a new technology that identifies immunogenic-gluten peptides without antibodies. It suggests that multiple detection approaches can improve food safety for celiac patients.
population_specificity: Genetically predisposed individuals with celiac disease, wheat sensitivity, or wheat allergy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide current information on the diagnosis and management of celiac disease, including the role of a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study highlights that a gluten-free diet is effective in managing celiac disease, with improvement observed in patients who adhere to it. The diagnosis must be correctly established due to the lifelong dietary requirement.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease (genetically predisposed individuals with compatible clinical features).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a gluten-free diet (GFD) compared to a gluten-containing diet (GD) influences functioning in children with autism spectrum disorders (ASD).
results_summary: The study found no differences between the GFD and GD groups in autistic symptoms, maladaptive behaviors, or intellectual abilities after the intervention, indicating that a GFD did not affect functioning in children with ASD.
population_specificity: Children aged 36-69 months with ASD and normal IQ (>70) who had been on a GFD for at least 8 weeks before enrollment.
effective_dosage: At least one normal meal containing gluten per day for the GD group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of gluten-free diet (GFD) in managing celiac disease (CeD) and investigate complementary strategies like gut microbiome modulation.
results_summary: The study found that GFD is the mainstay therapy for CeD but noted intestinal dysbiosis in CeD patients, regardless of GFD treatment. Probiotics were considered for microbiome modulation, but insufficient data supports their efficacy in treating CeD.
population_specificity: Celiac disease patients (untreated or treated with GFD) and healthy subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between celiac disease (CD) and anemia, particularly iron deficiency anemia, and the diagnostic approach for CD in cases of unexplained anemia.
results_summary: The study found that anemia, especially iron deficiency anemia, is a frequent extraintestinal manifestation of CD and should prompt suspicion of CD when no other etiology is identified. Diagnostic assessment includes antibody testing and, if positive, endoscopy with biopsy. Anemia in CD has a multifactorial pathogenesis, including deficiencies in iron, folate, or vitamin B12.
population_specificity: Individuals with celiac disease or unexplained anemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the nutritional quality and effects of a regular gluten-free diet (R-GFD) and a low-FODMAP gluten-free diet (LF-GFD) in celiac patients with persistent gastrointestinal symptoms.
results_summary: The study compared R-GFD and LF-GFD in celiac patients with persistent GI symptoms, but the abstract does not provide specific outcome results regarding efficacy or nutritional quality.
population_specificity: 46 celiac patients with persistent gastrointestinal symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and analyze the associations between celiac disease (CD) and skin diseases, as well as the potential pathogenic mechanisms involved, particularly focusing on the role of a gluten-free diet (GFD) in improving these manifestations.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet improves the manifestations of celiac disease, including various skin conditions, though many associations are based on case reports and small studies rather than large controlled trials. The pathogenic mechanisms, such as abnormal intestinal permeability, may contribute to dermatological manifestations in CD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease and associated skin manifestations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish a quantitative hierarchy of serum cytokines and their relation to symptoms in coeliac disease patients during gluten-mediated cytokine release reactions.
results_summary: The study found significant elevations in multiple cytokines (e.g., IL-2, CCL20, IL-6) after gluten challenge, with IL-2 and IL-17A rising earliest. Cytokine changes were strongly correlated with symptoms, and the most symptomatic patients had the highest elevations.
population_specificity: Coeliac disease patients on a gluten-free diet (n=25) and healthy volunteers (n=25).
effective_dosage: 10 g vital wheat gluten flour (single dose).
study_duration: Acute intervention (sera collected at baseline and 2, 4, and 6 hours post-challenge).

study_goal: To define the nature and time-course of symptoms and interleukin-2 changes specific for coeliac disease patients on a gluten-free diet after a gluten challenge.
results_summary: Serum interleukin-2 elevations correlated with symptom severity and timing after gluten exposure in coeliac disease patients, with symptoms peaking at 3 hours. Nausea and vomiting characterized severe reactions, while mild reactions included headache and tiredness.
population_specificity: 25 coeliac disease patients on a gluten-free diet and 25 healthy volunteers.
study_duration: 6 hours for symptom assessment, 48 hours for adverse event monitoring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of gluten-free diet (GFD) in managing irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) symptoms and compare its efficacy with other dietary therapies.
results_summary: Several RCTs demonstrated benefits of a GFD in IBS, though the mechanism of action remains uncertain. The abstract highlights concerns about potential nutritional inadequacies and gut microbiota alterations with restrictive diets like GFD.
population_specificity: Individuals with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of AMG 714, an anti-IL-15 monoclonal antibody, in patients with coeliac disease undergoing gluten challenge, to determine if it could prevent mucosal injury and alleviate symptoms.
results_summary: AMG 714 did not significantly prevent mucosal injury (measured by VHCD ratio) compared to placebo, but it showed some reduction in intraepithelial lymphocyte density and ameliorated clinical symptoms, particularly diarrhea. No serious adverse events were reported, though common side effects included gastrointestinal disorders and injection site reactions.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-80 with confirmed coeliac disease who had adhered to a gluten-free diet for at least 12 months before screening.
effective_dosage: 150 mg or 300 mg AMG 714 administered via subcutaneous injection every 2 weeks for 10 weeks (total six doses).
study_duration: 12 weeks (including 10 weeks of treatment and 2 weeks post-treatment follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent advances in the immunopathology, diagnostic biomarkers, and susceptibility determinants of gluten-related diseases, as well as potential new therapies.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that gluten-free diets are medically justified only for celiac disease and wheat allergy patients, while nonceliac gluten sensitivity remains debated. It summarizes recent scientific progress but notes ongoing controversy in the field.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease, IgE-mediated wheat allergy, and nonceliac gluten sensitivity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the complex interaction between gluten digestion, celiac disease, and gut microbiota, including the potential role of bacterial-origin enzymes in aiding gluten digestion.
results_summary: The study found that gluten presence/absence alters gut microbiota diversity and proportions, with dysbiosis observed in celiac disease patients. Bacterial-origin enzymes may help complete gluten digestion, suggesting potential as a coadjuvant treatment.
population_specificity: Young and adult patients with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a gluten-free diet, alone or combined with probiotic supplementation, on mental status, inflammation, and intestinal barrier function in patients with major depressive disorder.
results_summary: The study suggests that a gluten-free diet, particularly when combined with probiotics, may modulate the gut-brain-microbiota axis, potentially improving psychiatric symptoms and gut barrier function in MDD patients. However, specific results on efficacy are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: 120 outpatients with major depressive disorder (MDD).
effective_dosage: Not specified for gluten-free diet; probiotics included Lactobacillus helveticus R0052 and Bifidobacterium longum R0175.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe nutritional deficiencies in children with celiac disease on a gluten-free diet, discuss their clinical consequences, and identify strategies to address these imbalances.
results_summary: Children on a gluten-free diet are at risk of nutritional imbalances, including insufficient fiber, iron, vitamin D, and calcium, as well as altered intake of folate, magnesium, zinc, and high-glycemic-index foods. Nutritional education and fortified foods are recommended to mitigate these deficiencies.
population_specificity: Children with celiac disease on a gluten-free diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether a gluten-free diet could improve quality of life in patients with Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) compared to other diets.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet, along with low-FODMAP and balanced diets, reduced symptom severity in IBS patients, though no diet was superior in improving quality of life.
population_specificity: 42 patients with IBS according to Rome IV criteria (28 completed all three diets).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current understanding of celiac disease, including its pathophysiology, diagnosis, management, and the role of a gluten-free diet as the primary treatment.
results_summary: The study found that a lifelong, strict gluten-free diet improves quality of life, ameliorates symptoms, and prevents complications like refractory celiac disease and small intestinal malignancies. However, challenges remain in understanding certain phenotypes and developing alternative treatments.
population_specificity: General population with celiac disease, predominantly female, with a prevalence of approximately 1%.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the management of positive celiac serology in children, including the appropriateness of follow-up actions such as diagnostic biopsy or serial testing.
results_summary: The study found that 24.9% of children with positive TTG received no follow-up management, and among those with follow-up, 38.3% were inappropriately managed, often due to perceived false positives or lack of symptoms. Appropriate interventions included subspecialist referral or repeat testing to assess treatment response or asymptomatic cases.
population_specificity: Children under 18 years of age with positive tissue transglutaminase antibody (TTG) tests.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a gluten-free diet in treating celiac disease, focusing on symptom resolution and histological recovery.
results_summary: The study found that a strict gluten-free diet resolves symptoms and enables histological recovery in celiac disease patients, with mucosal healing emerging as an important prognostic factor.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease (gluten-induced enteropathy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of a gluten-free diet in managing dermatitis herpetiformis (DH), its diagnostic challenges, and its association with celiac disease.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet effectively improves DH, which is linked to celiac disease, though diagnostic criteria may need revision due to atypical presentations and inconsistent serological markers.
population_specificity: Individuals with dermatitis herpetiformis, particularly those with or without typical celiac disease markers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review updates on celiac disease diagnostics, including biopsy-sparing criteria, histopathology, and the role of a gluten-free diet in treatment and mucosal recovery.
results_summary: The study highlights that histologic evaluation remains essential for diagnosing celiac disease in non-responsive patients and assessing mucosal recovery post-treatment, though biopsy-sparing criteria have been validated in some cases. A gluten-free diet is implied as a standard treatment, but its specific efficacy is not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Individuals with celiac disease or suspected celiac disease, including those not responding to a gluten-free diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically appraise clinical practice guidelines (CPGs) on medical nutrition therapy (MNT) for celiac disease (CD) to identify areas needing improvement for better adherence and outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that all 12 reviewed CPGs were of low quality, with the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence guidelines scoring highest and others like the American Gastroenterology Association scoring lowest, highlighting the need for updated and improved guidelines.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease (CD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preoperative HIIT improves cardiorespiratory fitness and postoperative outcomes compared to standard hospital care.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found moderate-quality evidence that HIIT significantly improved cardiorespiratory fitness (measured by V̇o2 peak and 6MWT) and reduced postoperative complications, though no significant difference was observed in hospital length of stay.
population_specificity: Adult patients undergoing major surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically evaluate the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on lipid profile in the elderly population compared to other exercise modalities.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT was less effective than aerobic exercise (AE) in improving lipid profile metrics (TC, triglycerides, LDL-C, and HDL-C) in older adults, though specific HIIT results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Elderly adults (age not specified) with dyslipidemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a HIIT program combined with Nordic Curl exercises versus a HIIT-only program in improving performance metrics in futsal players.
results_summary: Both HIIT + NC and HIIT-only groups showed significant improvement in intermittent work performance, with no significant changes in body mass index or vertical jump performance. Isometric strength of quadriceps and hamstrings showed a trend of increase but was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Twenty-one futsal players (mean age ~21 years).
effective_dosage: HIIT circuit combined with 3 sets of 10 Nordic Curl repetitions (for the HIIT + NC group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if HIIT could increase left ventricular mass (LVM) and improve functional status and health-related quality of life (HRQoL) in individuals previously hospitalized for COVID-19.
results_summary: The study compared 12 weeks of supervised HIIT (4 × 4 min, three times a week) with standard care in post-COVID-19 patients, assessing LVM via cMRI and pulmonary diffusing capacity. Results suggested potential benefits, but full outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Individuals recently discharged from hospital due to COVID-19.
effective_dosage: 4 × 4 min sessions, three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of HIIT and MICT on inflammatory indices, adipokines, metabolic markers, body composition, cardiorespiratory fitness, and quality of life in breast cancer patients during adjuvant endocrine therapy.
results_summary: HIIT was found to be a safe, feasible, and time-efficient intervention that improved cardiovascular fitness in breast cancer patients. Both HIIT and MICT improved quality of life, though the abstract does not detail specific comparative outcomes for other measured markers.
population_specificity: Non-metastatic breast cancer patients during adjuvant endocrine therapy who had been treated with chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy.
effective_dosage: Supervised exercise intervention 3 times a week (intensity based on peak oxygen uptake).

study_goal: To determine the feasibility and acceptability of an mHealth, home-based HIIT intervention among stage II-III colorectal cancer survivors within 5-years post-resection and adjuvant therapy.
results_summary: The study reported high workout completion (88.6%) and retention rates (100%), no adverse events, and qualitative improvements in quality of life, though HIIT adherence to HR zones was lower (28.9% for high-intensity intervals). Participants expressed a desire to work harder.
population_specificity: Stage II-III colorectal cancer survivors within 5-years post-resection and adjuvant therapy (median age 39, 71% stage III).
effective_dosage: Not specified (HIIT vs. MICE prescription details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of various exercise training modes, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), in reducing resting blood pressure to inform optimal antihypertensive exercise prescriptions.
results_summary: HIIT significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure (-4.08/-2.50 mm Hg, p<0.001), though it ranked lower in effectiveness (SUCRA: 39.4% for SBP) compared to other exercise modes like isometric training. Secondary analyses did not highlight HIIT as the most effective submode for blood pressure reduction.
population_specificity: 15,827 participants from 270 randomized controlled trials (published 1990–2023) with a focus on resting blood pressure changes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of different types of chronic High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on glycaemic control, aerobic resistance, and body composition in individuals aged 18+ with type 2 diabetes (T2D).
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved glycaemic control, aerobic resistance, and body composition (reducing % fat and waist circumference) while maintaining fat-free mass in individuals with T2D. Compared to continuous aerobic training, HIIT showed an advantage in fasting blood glycemia, with subgroup analysis suggesting SI-HIIT and SIT-HIIT may be more effective for certain outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18+ with a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: Not specified (HIIT protocols varied but were not detailed in the abstract).
study_duration: Not specified (study duration not mentioned in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess and rank the comparative efficacy of six exercise modalities, including High-Intensity Interval Training, on physical fitness indicators in a school-based setting.
results_summary: High-Intensity Interval Training was the most effective intervention for reducing body mass index and improving physical fitness among the studied exercise modalities. The findings suggest it is a promising approach for school-based exercise programs.
population_specificity: 8,578 participants (48% girls) in school-based settings.

study_goal: To investigate whether high-intensity interval training reduces liver fat fraction and improves metabolic and inflammatory markers in individuals with chronic hepatitis B and hepatic steatosis.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, as the study appears to be ongoing or not yet concluded.
population_specificity: Thirty individuals with chronic hepatitis B and hepatic steatosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) for improving symptoms and disability in patients with migraine.
results_summary: The study assigned a C grade of recommendation to HIIT, indicating it may improve migraine symptoms and disability, but the evidence supporting its efficacy is less robust compared to other interventions like aerobic exercise or yoga.
population_specificity: Patients with migraine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of interval step exercise versus continuous walking exercise on cardiovascular parameters in post-menopausal hypertensive women.
results_summary: The study evaluated blood pressure, heart rate variability, and blood pressure reactivity after interval and continuous exercise sessions, but specific comparative results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Post-menopausal hypertensive women (n=12, age 59 ± 4 years, BMI 29.78 ± 4.10 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: Sessions lasted 120 minutes (specific exercise intensity/frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Single experimental sessions (no long-term intervention duration specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) versus moderate-intensity continuous aerobic training (MCT) on exercise tolerance in patients with heart failure (HF).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results but indicates the study is a systematic review and meta-analysis examining HIIT's effects on peak oxygen uptake (VO₂) in HF patients. The controversy around HIIT's efficacy suggests mixed or inconclusive findings.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure (HF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of 8-week polarized training (POL), high-intensity interval training (HIIT), and threshold training (THR) on cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) in untrained healthy young adults.
results_summary: Both POL and HIIT significantly increased ventilatory thresholds (VT) after 8 weeks, indicating improved CRF. The study did not report significant differences between HIIT and other training methods beyond VT improvements.
population_specificity: Untrained healthy young adults (n=36).
effective_dosage: HIIT was administered at 100% of Zone 3 intensity (based on ventilatory thresholds), with weekly training intensity distribution not further specified.

study_goal: To assess whether supervised high-intensity interval training reduces the need for inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) in untrained asthma patients.
results_summary: The study found that 63% of the exercise group had their ICS dose reduced by 25% or more compared to 50% in the control group, with a mean daily ICS dose reduction of 24% favoring the exercise group. The effect was sustained at 12 months, and the intervention was safe and well tolerated.
population_specificity: Untrained adults with symptomatic asthma who were treated with inhaled corticosteroids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the residual effects of a 12-week concurrent training program (power training + high-intensity interval training) on physical function and health-related quality of life in older adults with COPD.
results_summary: After 10 months of detraining, the intervention group showed improved physical function, health-related quality of life, early rate of force development, and maximum muscle power, while preserving muscle thickness and peak pulmonary oxygen uptake.
population_specificity: Older adults with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), aged 76.9 ± 6.8 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the feasibility, safety, adherence, and efficacy of HIIT versus MICT in improving functioning and health-related quality of life in COVID-19 survivors.
results_summary: The abstract describes the study design but does not report results, as it appears to be a protocol for a future randomized controlled trial.
population_specificity: COVID-19 survivors aged >18 years admitted to a specialized post-COVID center.
effective_dosage: HIIT: 4 × 4 minutes at 85-90% peak heart rate, biweekly for 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the relationships between cardiac adipose tissue (CAT), physical activity (PA), and physical fitness (PFit), and to explore the effects of different exercise modalities, including HIIT, in women with obesity.
results_summary: The study found negative correlations between CAT and vigorous physical activity (VPA). The pilot intervention compared HIIT, HICT, and control groups, but specific outcomes for HIIT were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 26 women with obesity (age: 23.41 ± 5.78 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-intensity interval training (HIIT) is more beneficial than moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) for improving markers of brain health in sedentary middle-aged adults.
results_summary: The abstract does not report results, as the study appears to be in progress or recently completed without published outcomes.
population_specificity: Sedentary middle-aged adults (45-65 years)
effective_dosage: ~50-minute sessions, 3 days per week (volume-matched between HIIT and MICT)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to perform a large-scale meta-analysis to evaluate the effects of HIIT on cardiometabolic health in the general population.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of 97 RCTs involving 3399 participants found that HIIT significantly improved 14 clinically relevant cardiometabolic health parameters, including peak aerobic capacity (VO₂ max).
population_specificity: General population

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) and moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on executive function and cerebral blood flow (CBF) mechanisms in young adults.
results_summary: The study found that MICT improved executive function and CBF more effectively than HIIT, with significant improvements in TMT completion time and CBF indices (PI, RI, S/D). HIIT did not show comparable benefits in these outcomes.
population_specificity: Healthy young adults (mean age 25.23 ± 2.18 years, 49.82% male).
effective_dosage: 40 minutes of HIIT, three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare maternal and fetal cardiovascular responses to acute bouts of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) versus moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) during pregnancy.
results_summary: The study found that both HIIT and MICT were well tolerated by mothers and fetuses, with higher maternal heart rates observed during HIIT. No adverse effects were reported for either exercise type.
population_specificity: Fifteen pregnant women (27.3 ± 3.5 weeks of gestation, 33 ± 4 years of age) with singleton pregnancies.
effective_dosage: HIIT consisted of 10 × 1-min intervals at ≥90% maximum heart rate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-intensity interval training could mitigate orthostatic intolerance in older adults following prolonged bedrest.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in orthostatic tolerance between the exercise and control groups post-bedrest, with most participants failing to complete the tilt test. High-intensity exercise did not appear to improve outcomes compared to no exercise.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults (55-65 years old, 11 female).
effective_dosage: Not specified (high-intensity, aerobic, and resistance exercises were included).
study_duration: 14 days of bedrest with exercise intervention during this period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on arterial stiffness and cardio-metabolic parameters in obese hypertensive women.
results_summary: The study found that 12 weeks of HIIT significantly improved arterial stiffness indicators (AIx@75HR and o-PWV) and lowered cardio-metabolic risk factors, including total cholesterol, HDL-cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol, and triglycerides.
population_specificity: Obese hypertensive women aged 40-50 years.
effective_dosage: 4 minutes of cycling at 85-90% of peak HR, interspersed with 3-minute active recovery at 60-70% of peak HR, three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review literature on common orthopaedic injuries in CrossFit athletes to aid clinicians in diagnosis, treatment, and prevention.
results_summary: The study found that the most common CrossFit injuries occur in the shoulder (25%), spine (14%), and knee (13%), with improper form and prior injury exacerbation being primary causes. Male athletes and unsupervised training were associated with higher injury rates.
population_specificity: CrossFit athletes (primarily male and female adults).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of HIIT and combined HIIT programs compared to usual care in reducing cancer-related fatigue and pain in adult cancer patients and survivors.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT and combined HIIT interventions significantly reduced cancer-related fatigue and cancer-associated pain, with moderate to large effect sizes and statistical significance (P < 0.001).
population_specificity: Adult cancer patients and survivors (>18 years old).

study_goal: To systematically evaluate the safety and efficacy of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) in improving body shape, cardiorespiratory fitness, and metabolic risk markers of cardiovascular disease in children and adolescents.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved cardiorespiratory fitness indicators (VO2max, SBP, DBP, HRmax) and some cardiovascular disease biomarkers (TC, HDL-C) but had no significant effect on body shape indicators (BMI, BF%, WC) or other biomarkers (TG, LDL-C). The study concluded that HIIT can be promoted to improve cardiorespiratory fitness and reduce some metabolic risks in this population.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents (2995 participants across 47 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) versus Moderate-Intensity Continuous Training (MICT) on central blood pressure (cBP) and related cardiovascular outcomes.
results_summary: HIIT was superior to MICT in reducing central systolic blood pressure (cSBP) and peripheral systolic blood pressure (pSBP), as well as increasing maximal oxygen uptake (VO2max). No significant differences were found for central diastolic blood pressure (cDBP), peripheral diastolic blood pressure (pDBP), or pulse wave velocity (PWV).
population_specificity: 163 patients enrolled in six randomized controlled trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of exercise, including high-intensity interval training, on psychopathology and clinical markers in patients with schizophrenia.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that exercise, particularly aerobic and high-intensity interval training, significantly improved schizophrenia psychopathology and other clinical outcomes, with superior benefits over other modalities.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18-65 diagnosed with schizophrenia disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) versus Moderate-Intensity Continuous Training (MCT) in individuals with Primary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis (PPMS) to determine potential benefits for symptom management and rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT was superior to MCT in improving health-related quality of life, MS symptoms, and performance impediments in PPMS patients, though generalizability to this subpopulation was previously unclear. The trial design allows for explicit recommendations on endurance training in PPMS.
population_specificity: Individuals with Primary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis (pwPPMS).
effective_dosage: HIIT sessions included six 90-second intervals at 95% peak heart rate, performed 2-3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) on transcriptomic age (a measure of biological age) and other health markers in sedentary adults.
results_summary: HIIT reduced transcriptomic age by 3.59 years, improved mental health scores (PHQ-9, PSQI), and enhanced body composition (BMI, body fat mass, visceral fat). Gene expression analysis suggested HIIT may influence age-related pathways like autophagy and insulin signaling.
population_specificity: Sedentary adults aged 40-65 years.
effective_dosage: Three 23-minute HIIT sessions per week (10 × 1-minute intervals per session).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, safety, and efficacy of a periodized boxing training program featuring high-intensity interval training (HIIT) for individuals with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study found high adherence (97.7%) and no withdrawals, with only minor injuries reported. Nine of 10 participants showed improvement in motor scores, suggesting potential efficacy of HIIT in this population.
population_specificity: Ten individuals with early-stage Parkinson's disease without contraindications to intense exercise.
effective_dosage: Three 1-hour sessions per week for 15 weeks, including warmup and noncontact boxing rounds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the motivational effects, perceived benefits, harms, and barriers of supervised high-intensity interval training during and after neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy in rectal cancer patients.
results_summary: Supervised exercise during therapy was perceived as more controllable, enjoyable, and less difficult than anticipated, while unsupervised post-therapy exercise was more enjoyable and less difficult but less controllable. Common benefits included improved cardiovascular endurance, physical functioning, and quality of life, while harms included exacerbation of treatment side effects.
population_specificity: Rectal cancer patients undergoing neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy.
study_duration: During and after neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the role of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) in managing visceral adiposity and generalized obesity within multidisciplinary cardiac rehabilitation.
results_summary: The abstract suggests HIIT is a promising regime for inducing metabolic adaptations and targeting visceral fat oxidation, but notes under-utilization and a lack of local published data.
population_specificity: Individuals with visceral adiposity or generalized obesity, particularly in the context of cardiometabolic disease prevention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether IL-6 signaling inhibition impairs cardiac and metabolic adaptations to HIIT compared to TNF inhibition in RA patients.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so no results are reported in the abstract. Outcomes will include changes in left ventricular mass and visceral fat mass measured by MRI.
population_specificity: 80 RA patients treated with IL-6 inhibitors (n=40) or TNF inhibitors (n=40).
effective_dosage: 3 weekly HIIT sessions of 4×4 min on an ergometer bicycle.
interactions: Interaction with IL-6 and TNF inhibitors is a focus of the study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of HIIT and increased physical activity on IGF-1 levels, executive functions, and other health-related variables in young sedentary women.
